explanation: Designed by Antoni Gaudí, the exterior merges Gothic structural forms (pointed arches, vertical towers, flying buttresses) with Art Nouveau organic ornamentation and Catalan Modernisme naturalistic motifs.
evidence: Wikipedia: "The design combines Gothic and curvilinear Art Nouveau forms." UNESCO World Heritage inscription confirms the Gothic-Art Nouveau fusion.

explanation: The 42-story tower (1926-37) exterior combines Collegiate Gothic detailing (pointed arches, tracery, gargoyles) with Art Deco skyscraper massing, setbacks, and streamlined vertical emphasis.
evidence: SAH Archipedia: "Mixed with the Gothic is plenty of Art Deco streamlining." Pittsburgh History & Landmarks Foundation confirms the Gothic-Deco hybrid.

explanation: The 1925 tower exterior features a French Gothic Revival crown (modeled on Rouen Cathedral's Butter Tower with flying buttresses) atop an Art Deco-influenced vertical shaft with setbacks.
evidence: Chicago Architecture Center: Designed by Hood & Howells, combining "Gothic Revival style" with modern skyscraper form. Winner of 1922 competition for Gothic design on modern tower.

explanation: The exterior displays Romano-Byzantine style: Byzantine influence in the large travertine domes and Greek-cross plan; Romanesque in the rounded arches, thick walls, and fortress-like massing.
evidence: Wikipedia: "The basilica was designed by Paul Abadie in the Romano-Byzantine style." Features "a large central dome and multiple smaller domes" characteristic of Byzantine churches.

building: Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi
explanation: The 13th-century exterior shows two distinct phases: the Lower Basilica (1228-30) in heavy Romanesque style with rounded arches; the Upper Basilica in Italian Gothic with pointed arches and rose window.
evidence: Wikipedia: "The lower church is...in the Romanesque style...The upper church is in the Italian Gothic style." UNESCO World Heritage site documentation confirms the dual-style construction.
file_1: Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi_1.jpg
file_2: Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi_2.jpg

explanation: Bertram Goodhue's 1926 exterior combines Art Deco geometric massing with Egyptian Revival elements: stepped pyramid crown, pylon-like entrance portals, and pharaonic symbolic ornamentation.
evidence: LA Public Library archives: "Pylon-like shapes resemble ancient Egyptian temples...together with the pyramid that crowns the tower." LA Conservancy identifies it as "Egyptian-flavored Art Deco."

explanation: The 1888 terminus exterior fuses British Victorian Gothic (pointed arches, turrets, stone tracery) with Indo-Saracenic elements (Mughal domes, Indian pavilions, decorative tilework).
evidence: UNESCO World Heritage: "Outstanding example of late 19th-century railway architecture...Victorian Gothic Revival architecture blended with themes deriving from Indian traditional architecture."

explanation: Horace Walpole's villa (1749-77) exterior pioneered Georgian Gothic: a Georgian-era symmetrical structure overlaid with medieval Gothic Revival details including battlements, tracery windows, and pinnacles.
evidence: Strawberry Hill House Trust: "Britain's finest example of Georgian Gothic Revival architecture." English Heritage confirms it as "the first significant building of the Gothic Revival."

explanation: Philip Johnson's 1984 tower exterior epitomizes Postmodernism with Neoclassical/Beaux-Arts references: pink granite base with giant columns, tripartite classical composition, and the iconic Chippendale broken pediment crown.
evidence: Wikipedia: "The building is considered an iconic example of postmodern architecture." AIA Guide to NYC notes the "Chippendale top" and classical granite base as deliberate historical references.

explanation: The 1869-86 castle exterior blends Romanesque Revival (rounded arches, fortress massing, thick walls) with Gothic Revival elements (pointed towers, ornate windows, vertical emphasis).
evidence: Wikipedia: "Romanesque Revival palace...built in a romanticised interpretation of the Middle Ages." Bavarian Palace Administration describes the blend of Romanesque and Gothic forms.

explanation: The exterior displays three periods: core Byzantine structure (five domes, Greek-cross plan), Gothic additions (13th-14th c. pointed arches, spires, tracery), and Romanesque elements (rounded portal arches, sculptural reliefs).
evidence: Wikipedia: "Italo-Byzantine architecture" with later additions. UNESCO notes "a unique blend of Eastern and Western influences." Exterior shows visible layering of Byzantine domes with Gothic pinnacles.

explanation: The 1854 palace exterior is a Romantic-era pastiche combining Neo-Gothic elements (crenellated towers, pointed arches, Manueline details) with Baroque theatrical ornamentation and vivid color.
evidence: Wikipedia: "Eclectic styles include Neo-Gothic, Neo-Manueline, Neo-Islamic and Neo-Renaissance." UNESCO: "One of the major expressions of 19th-century Romanticism in the world."

explanation: The 1971 tower exterior synthesizes ancient Persian motifs (Achaemenid/Sassanid-inspired arches, Persepolis-style proportions) with International Style modernist geometry and white marble cladding.
evidence: Architect Hossein Amanat designed it to blend "Achaemenid architecture inspired by Persepolis" with "Sassanid elliptical arches" in modern form. Iranian Cultural Heritage documentation confirms the fusion.

building: Cathedral of St. John the Divine
explanation: The cathedral exterior literally embodies two phases: Byzantine-Romanesque east end (1892-1909) with rounded arches and domes; Gothic Revival nave and west front (post-1909) with pointed arches and tracery.
evidence: NYC Landmarks Conservancy: "Begun in 1892 in the Byzantine-Romanesque style...By 1909 the plan was updated to the more fashionable Gothic style." The transition is architecturally visible.
file_1: Cathedral of St. John the Divine_1.jpg
file_2: Cathedral of St. John the Divine_2.jpg

explanation: The 500 BCE ceremonial capital exterior shows Achaemenid imperial style fusing Persian, Egyptian (cavetto cornices, column forms), and Mesopotamian influences in its monumental staircases and columned halls.
evidence: Wikipedia: "The Achaemenids developed a hybrid imperial style drawing on influences from Mesopotamia, Egypt and Lydia." Archaeological evidence shows Egyptian artisans worked on the site.

explanation: Christopher Wren's exterior (1675-1711) combines English Baroque grandeur (dramatic dome, sculptural ornamentation) with Palladian classical restraint (symmetrical façade, columned portico, geometric proportions).
evidence: Wikipedia: "English Baroque style." Architectural historians note Wren's synthesis of Italian Baroque drama with Palladian classical order, visible in the dome and western facade composition.

explanation: The palace exterior (expanded 1661-1715) shows French Baroque opulence (elaborate ornamentation, dramatic scale) ordered by Palladian classical principles (symmetry, columned facades, rational proportions).
evidence: Wikipedia: "French Baroque or French Classicism." Architectural analysis confirms Louis Le Vau and Jules Hardouin-Mansart's fusion of Baroque grandeur with classical Palladian symmetry.

explanation: The 1902 exterior combines Chicago School structural innovation (steel frame enabling the triangular form, large windows) with Beaux-Arts decorative program (Renaissance-inspired terracotta ornamentation, classical composition).
evidence: Wikipedia: "Beaux-Arts design by Daniel Burnham." NYC Landmarks notes the Chicago School steel-frame structure clad in Beaux-Arts terra-cotta detailing.

explanation: Louis Sullivan's 1899 exterior exemplifies Chicago School rationalism (steel frame, "Chicago windows," horizontal emphasis) with Art Nouveau ornament (elaborate cast-iron botanical designs at the entrance).
evidence: Wikipedia: "Chicago School commercial style...with ornament designed in the Art Nouveau style." The cast-iron entrance ornamentation is widely cited as Sullivan's masterpiece of Art Nouveau metalwork.

explanation: Domènech i Montaner's 1908 exterior fuses Catalan Modernisme/Art Nouveau (flowing forms, mosaic ornamentation, floral motifs) with Gothic structural elements (pointed arches, rose window, buttresses).
evidence: UNESCO World Heritage: "Catalan Art Nouveau...exuberant Art Nouveau decoration." Wikipedia notes Gothic structural references within the Modernisme decorative vocabulary.

explanation: The 1914 cathedral exterior displays Romano-Byzantine style: Romanesque heavy masonry and rounded arches combined with Byzantine dome composition, inspired by churches like Hagia Sophia and San Vitale.
evidence: Cathedral website: "Byzantine architecture" with "Romanesque structural elements." Architectural historians classify it as Romano-Byzantine, similar to Sacré-Cœur Paris.

explanation: Raymond Hood's 1931 tower exterior (570 Lexington Ave) fuses Gothic verticality and crown composition with Art Deco geometric abstraction, setbacks, and machine-age ornamental vocabulary.
evidence: AIA Guide to NYC identifies it as Gothic-influenced Art Deco. Architectural historians cite Hood's synthesis of "Gothic vertical emphasis" with "Art Deco streamlining" in the terracotta crown.

explanation: The 1939 station exterior blends Spanish Colonial Revival (arcaded courtyards, clay tile roofs, stucco walls, mission-style massing) with Art Deco geometric detailing and streamlined modernism.
evidence: Wikipedia: "Combination of Spanish Colonial Revival, Mission Revival and streamline Moderne." LA Conservancy: "Last of the great American railway stations" combining Colonial and Art Deco.

explanation: The 1929 church exterior in Tulsa combines Gothic ecclesiastical typology (tower, pointed forms, vertical emphasis) with Art Deco geometric ornamentation, prairie-influenced sculpture, and modern materials.
evidence: National Historic Landmark nomination: "Outstanding example of Art Deco ecclesiastical architecture." Architectural historians cite it as one of the finest Gothic-Art Deco church designs in America.

explanation: Charles Garnier's 1875 opera house exterior epitomizes Beaux-Arts (symmetry, classical vocabulary, axial composition) infused with Baroque theatricality (dramatic sculptural groups, rich ornamentation, spatial dynamism).
evidence: Wikipedia: "Beaux-Arts architecture" and "Napoleon III style." Garnier explicitly incorporated Baroque spatial drama into the classical Beaux-Arts framework. French Ministry of Culture confirms classification.
